articles.contents:

Hello!
Technology
Selected Coursework
Resume




Hello!
My name is John Kim, and I was born and raised in Los Angeles, California. My hobbies include traveling, watching eSports (#C9WIN), learning Japanese, and seeking out delicious new places to eat throughout SoCal and the East Coast. I also love to sing, even though I’m not any good at it! Feel free to ask me about my favorite restaurants and foodie moments!
Technology
R, Java, Python, SQL

articles.title: Coding
articles.description: A portolio of selected programming projects I've completed.
articles.contents:
Contents
Austin Bikeshare
Princeton Room Draw 2021
Kaggle Tabular Playground Series July 2021

Austin Bikeshare




A web app featuring a map of the Austin Bcycle system and available bikes, as well as data visualizations on when and where certain bike types will be available. Serves as a companion web app for an in-development Alexa skill of the same name, allowing Austin Bcycle commuters to conveniently check their home station, plan their commute, and predict when bikes or docks will be available.
Inspired by my own experience as an Austin Bcycle commuter during the summer of 2021.
Princeton Room Draw 2021
A simple web app published during Princeton’s annual dorm selection lottery, updated to reflect room changes and additional student populations during COVID-19. Original dorm listings published by Princeton Housing used an unorganized pdf of room listings; this web app simplified the process by allowing sorting by room type, square footage, and college affiliation, as well as allowing students to check their status in the lottery.
With the end of Room Draw in June, app is no longer in development; current deployment displays model rooms and removes student ID functionality to preserve privacy. Heroku deployment available here.
Kaggle Tabular Playground Series July 2021
For Kaggle’s Tabular Playground Series July 2021 machine learning competition, I wrote a full solution in R using tidy principles, including time series analysis, feature engineering, and modeling, that placed in the top 30% (at time of posting). The model was an ensemble between a hyperparameter-tuned boosted tree (XGBoost) and Random Forest (ranger) to predict carbon, benzene, and nitrogen oxide pollution based on weather sensor data.
Code available here.

Power in Public Spheres
Ex Ante Moral Hazard in Health Insurance

Power in Public Spheres

Second stage: \[\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
FundsAlloc_{st} &= \beta{}_0 + \beta{}_1(\widehat{X_{PropHiIncome}})_{st} + \beta{}_2(RPP_{st}) + 
\beta{}_3(Young Pop_{st}) + \beta{}_4(Extract Employees_{st})\\
& + \beta_5{}(GOP Legis_{st}) + \beta_6{}(Split Legis_{st}) + \gamma{}_s + \lambda{}_t + \epsilon
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}\]
First stage: \[\begin{equation}
\begin{aligned}
(X_{PropHiIncome})_{st} &= \nu{}_0 + \nu{}_1(RPP_{st}) + \nu_2{}(Young Pop_{st}) + 
\nu{}_3(Extract Employees_{st})  \\
& + \nu{}_4(GOPLegis_{st}) + \nu{}_5(Split Legis_{st}) + \nu{}_6(Z_{Extract GDP})_{st} + \mu{}_s+ \rho{}_t + \epsilon
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}\]
Following Doyle (2007), I use Instrumental Variables regression (using proportion of state GDP allocated to natural resources as an instrument) to estimate the causal effect of increased votership by upper-middle class Americans on proportion of state funds allocated to public higher education. I find no significant causal effect (\(p > 0.1\)), despite evidence that upper-middle class Americans are disproportionately more likely to benefit from spending on public higher education.

Using data from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (Add Health), I use Covariate Balancing Propensity Score matching (Imai and Ratkovic, 2014) alongside logistic regression to evaluate whether gaining health insurance was associated with any increase in illegal drug use, a common form of risky health behavior, among American adults. I find that gaining health insurance was not associated with any increase in odds of illegal drug use at a statistically significant level (\(p>0.1\)), controlling for previous drug use, stress, income, race, sex, and age. Using an analysis-of-variance (ANOVA) test, I conclude that models with interaction terms do not explain more variation at a statistically significant level (\(Chi>0.08\)).

articles.title: Experience
articles.description: My professional experiences, displayed in a professional format.
articles.contents:
Contents
Professional
Yext
Research Assistant
Texas Office of the Attorney General
IssueVoter

Teaching

Professional
Yext
I am an incoming intern at Yext as a Technical Engagement Management Intern.
Research Assistant
I am a research assistant for Prof. Matias Iarcyzower, focusing on building AI/ML models alongside game theory to examine the interplay of money and politics.
Texas Office of the Attorney General
I worked at the Texas Attorney General’s office as part of its nonpartisan Consumer Protection Division. There, I published privileged research and reports involving advertising technology and consumer data protection. To this end, I compiled, interpreted, and presented technical codebases, documentations, and expert statements/depositions on behalf of a lay audience of assistant attorneys general regarding ongoing confidential litigation in the tech industry. Specific issues I worked on include cryptography, protected categories in unsupervised clustering, privacy-utility optimization, and data protection in machine learning.
As a final project, I collaborated with 4 other interns from the Attorney General’s offices of Iowa and DC to present on US privacy standards to a nationwide coalition of Attorney General’s offices, with representatives from all 50 states.
IssueVoter
I previously worked at IssueVoter as a Business Development Intern, where I managed IssueVoter’s CRM platform on Airtable and helped launch its civic engagement workshop series. I also authored several bill summaries, direct pieces of content launched on the IssueVoter website.
Teaching
I am currently an Undergraduate Course Assistant for Princeton’s Department of Economics, where I TA for ECO310 - Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach under Professor Can Urgun. I am also an R Programming consultant for the McGraw Center for Teaching and Learning.
I was previously a course tutor for Princeton University courses through McGraw. I tutored for MAT175 - Mathematics for Economics/Life Sciences and POL345 - Introduction to Quantitative Social Science.

articles.title: John Kim
articles.description: Politics buff, aspiring technologist, and foodie!
articles.contents:
At a Glance
I am a student at Princeton University studying political economy and technology. I am particularly interested in quantitative and computational social science, with applications to machine learning, causal inference, and technology policy. I am currently seeking roles in data science & management/PM.
I most recently served as a Technical Engagement Management Intern at Yext.
For more about me, as well as a copy of my resume, see my bio.
Academic
A.B. Economics, Princeton University ’23
Program in Political Economy, Departments of Politics & Economics
Certificate in Applications of Computing, Department of Computer Science
Awards and Fellowships
2021: Public Interest Technology Fellow, Center for Information Technology Policy
Fully funded program to gain first-hand experience in technology policy. Includes a training bootcamp in technology policy, placement in a government agency working on public interest technology, and a stipend.
2020: Osawa Fellow, Princeton in Asia
Fully funded program to live and teach English in Tokyo, Japan on behalf of various schools and businesses, as well as a stipend for independent travel around Japan. Rescinded due to COVID-19.
2019: QuestBridge Match Scholar, QuestBridge
Scholarship program for low-income, high-achieving high school students to attend top universities across the US. Provided admission and scholarship to attend Princeton University, valued at $200k+.

articles.title: Other
articles.description: Some other cool stuff that I work on that I'm proud of!
articles.contents:
Contents
Princeton University Nonprofit Consulting
The Citizens’ Campaign
Aspire Coffeeworks

Princeton Model Congress
Rehack

Princeton University Nonprofit Consulting

I am currently a consultant for PUNC. Each semester, 6-8 other team members and I work with a nonprofit organization in pro bono consulting work, concluding with a project presentation to both the nonprofit and the entire PUNC club. See organizations I’ve worked with below.
The Citizens’ Campaign
We helped the Citizens’ Campaign release their civic engagement curriculum. This primarily consisted of designing and analyzing a survey to local community college professors regarding implementing the curriculum.
Aspire Coffeeworks
We helped Aspire Coffeeworks market their product to the Chicagoland area. This included a complete redesign of their branding, competitor analysis, pitching to local stores, and researching entryways into online markets.
Princeton Model Congress

America’s oldest model congress conference held in Washington DC. As one of PMC’s elected Directors of Administration for two years, I am in charge of conference logistics running up to and day-of the event. For 2020, I (along with my fellow DAs) were able to successfully plan and execute Princeton Model Congress 2020 virtually using the Attendify platform.
Rehack

The first-ever reverse hackathon, emphasizing a beginner-friendly approach where competitors redesign and implement existing tech in a more meaningful, socially responsible way. For Rehack’s virtual hackathons in 2020 and 2021, I led marketing to bring West Coast universities to Rehack for the first time. As a result, 9 West Coast universities fielded at least one team to compete at Rehack for the first time.
